questions.q: How many finger widths should be between the axilla and the crutch pad?
questions.rationale: This gap prevents pressure on the axillary nerve, which can cause paralysis.

questions.q: What is the correct elbow flexion for crutch walking?
questions.rationale: 30 degrees allows for optimal leverage and weight bearing on the hands.

questions.q: Describe the 2-point crutch gait.
options: Move one crutch then same foot
Move crutch and opposite foot together
Move both crutches then both feet
questions.rationale: In 2-point gait, the right crutch and left foot move simultaneously, simulating normal walking arm swing.

questions.q: Which gait is used for a broken leg (non-weight bearing)?
questions.rationale: 3-point gait takes all weight on the crutches and the "good" leg, protecting the broken one.

questions.q: Which gait provides the most stability but is slowest?
questions.rationale: 4-point gait always has 3 points of contact on the ground at any time, providing max stability.

questions.q: Which gait is typically used by paraplegics with braces?
questions.rationale: They plant crutches and swing the paralyzed legs forward using momentum.

questions.q: When going UP stairs with crutches, which moves first?
questions.rationale: The good leg powers the lift up the step. "Up with the Good".

questions.q: On which side should a patient hold a cane?
questions.rationale: Holding it on the strong side widens the base of support and reduces load on the weak hip.

questions.q: What is the correct sequence for walking with a cane?
options: Cane + Weak leg, then Strong leg
Cane, then Strong leg, then Weak leg
Strong leg, then Cane, then Weak leg
questions.rationale: The cane supports the weak leg as they move forward together.

questions.q: What is the correct technique for a standard walker?
options: Pick up, set down, walk to it
questions.rationale: Standard walkers have no wheels; they must be lifted to ensure stability before stepping.

questions.q: Where should a patient tie belongings on a walker?
questions.rationale: Tying heavy items to the front bar shifts the center of gravity and causes the walker to tip forward.

questions.q: How should a patient stand up from a chair to use a walker?
questions.rationale: Pulling on the walker can pull it over on top of the patient. Push off the sturdy chair.

questions.q: Why handle a wet cast with palms only?
questions.rationale: Fingertips cause indentations in wet plaster which dry into pressure points causing ulcers.

questions.q: What does a specific "hot spot" on a dry cast indicate?
questions.rationale: A localized hot spot indicates inflammation/infection of the tissue beneath the cast.

questions.q: A foul odor coming from a cast suggests?
questions.rationale: Foul, necrotic smells indicate anaerobic infection or skin breakdown.

questions.q: What is "petaling" a cast?
options: Padding the rough edges with tape
questions.rationale: Petaling involves overlapping tape strips on the edge to prevent the rough plaster from cutting the skin.

questions.q: What is the earliest sign of compartment syndrome?
questions.rationale: Pain that persists despite medication is the hallmark early warning. Pulselessness is a late sign.

questions.q: Where should traction weights be positioned?
questions.rationale: If weights touch the floor, the traction force is lost. They must hang free to provide tension.

questions.q: What is the purpose of Buck's traction?
questions.rationale: Buck's is temporary skin traction used pre-op to stop painful muscle spasms in hip fractures.

questions.q: What is a major risk with skeletal traction?
questions.rationale: The pins penetrate the bone, creating a direct pathway for bacteria to cause bone infection.

questions.q: What technique is used for skeletal pin care?
questions.rationale: Because the pins enter the bone, sterile technique is required to prevent osteomyelitis.

questions.q: Can the nurse release skeletal traction weights?
questions.rationale: Releasing skeletal traction can cause the bone fragments to shift, causing damage. Never release it.

questions.q: What position must be avoided after hip replacement?
questions.rationale: Adduction (crossing legs) can pop the prosthetic head out of the socket (dislocation).

questions.q: Why should a BKA patient lie prone?
questions.rationale: Sitting creates hip flexion; lying prone stretches the hip flexor to prevent permanent contracture.

questions.q: How should the nurse treat phantom limb pain?
questions.rationale: Phantom pain is neuropathic and real to the patient; it requires analgesic treatment.

questions.q: Is Rheumatoid Arthritis symmetric or asymmetric?
questions.rationale: RA is systemic and autoimmune, so it attacks joints bilaterally (both hands, both knees).

questions.q: What exacerbates OA pain?
questions.rationale: OA is mechanical wear; using the joint (activity) causes pain, rest relieves it.

questions.q: Which food should be avoided in Gout?
questions.rationale: Organ meats and sardines are high in purines, which break down into uric acid.

questions.q: What is the classic sign of Fat Embolism?
questions.rationale: Fat globules block capillaries in the skin, causing a petechial rash on the chest/axilla.

questions.q: How long must a scoliosis brace be worn?
questions.rationale: Braces are only effective if worn continuously, usually removed only for showering (1 hr).

questions.q: What is Kyphosis?
questions.rationale: Kyphosis is the exaggerated forward rounding of the upper back.

questions.q: What is Lordosis?
questions.rationale: Lordosis is the inward curve of the lumbar spine, often seen in pregnancy or obesity.

questions.q: Memory trick for stairs with crutches?
options: Up with Good, Down with Bad
Up with Bad, Down with Good
questions.rationale: The "Good" leg powers you up against gravity; gravity helps the "Bad" leg go down.

questions.q: How high should a cane handle be?
questions.rationale: The greater trochanter level allows for the necessary 30-degree elbow flexion.

questions.q: Why are tennis balls sometimes put on walkers?
questions.rationale: They help the walker slide, but can be a safety hazard if the walker slides away.

questions.q: What device is used post-Total Knee Replacement?
questions.rationale: CPM machines keep the knee moving to prevent scar tissue adhesion and stiffness.

questions.q: What is the treatment duration for Osteomyelitis?
questions.rationale: Bone is poorly vascularized, so long-term IV therapy is needed to penetrate and kill bacteria.

questions.q: How do you turn a laminectomy patient?
questions.rationale: Log rolling maintains spinal alignment and prevents twisting which could damage the surgical site.

questions.q: What is the priority assessment for Cervical Laminectomy?
questions.rationale: Cervical nerves control the diaphragm and arms; impairment causes respiratory arrest.

questions.q: What is the priority assessment for Lumbar Laminectomy?
questions.rationale: Lumbar nerves control the bladder and legs; retention is a common complication.

questions.q: What is the priority assessment for Thoracic Laminectomy?
questions.rationale: Thoracic nerves innervate the abdominal muscles (cough) and gut.

questions.q: What activity is restricted after laminectomy?
questions.rationale: Sitting puts maximal stress on the spine. Patients should lie or walk, not sit.

questions.q: What type of fracture in a child suggests abuse?
questions.rationale: Spiral fractures result from twisting force, which is rare in accidental falls.

questions.q: Who typically gets Greenstick fractures?
questions.rationale: Children's bones are softer and tend to bend/splinter rather than snap cleanly.

questions.q: What is the priority for an open fracture?
questions.rationale: Infection (Osteomyelitis) is the major risk; cover to protect until surgery.

questions.q: What safety item is needed for Halo Traction?
questions.rationale: In case of CPR, the vest might need to be released quickly.

questions.q: What test checks for Carpal Tunnel?
questions.rationale: Phalen's (flexing wrists back to back) reproduces the numbness/tingling.

questions.q: What is a sign of Paget's disease?
questions.rationale: Abnormal bone remodeling leads to thick, soft, deformed bones (hat size increases).

questions.q: What area is affected by Ankylosing Spondylitis?
questions.rationale: Inflammation fuses the vertebrae, causing a rigid, "bamboo" spine.
